40% in survey support a state bailout for MBTA

Support for plugging the cash-strapped MBTA’s budget gap with state dollars was most robust inside Route 128, according to a Boston Globe poll. (Boston Globe)

Schools fear gains will fade as funds end

Boston is using
nearly $26 million in federal grants in hopes
of turning around
12 persistently low-achieving public schools. (Boston Globe)

Plane crash in Siberia kills most on board

A passenger plane crashed shortly after taking off Monday, killing 31 of the 43 people on board, officials said. The survivors were in serious condition. (AP)

Romney sides with Wis.
governor in divisive recall

In supporting Governor Scott Walker, Mitt Romney is stepping into the middle of a nationally watched battle over workers’ rights and collective bargaining.
Opinion | Adrian Walker

A mayor under fire

You know things are bad for Willy Lantigua when you find the embattled mayor of Lawrence having lunch alone in a little back room in City Hall.

Middleborough faults tribe
over abandoned casino deal

The town is seeking compensation from the Mashpee Wampanoag tribe, which had made casino plans with Middleborough before shifting sights to Taunton.

iRobot turns to the nuclear industry

The Bedford company, which is seeking new markets as Pentagon cuts loom, is expected to announce its first sale to a domestic nuclear power plant operator.

Apps help you find drug discounts

Honest Discounts LLC, a Boston start-up, is launching a series of mobile apps to help consumers find savings on prescription drugs at pharmacy outlets.

MIT engineers look at roadside safety

Professor Seth Teller is leading an effort to try to create life-saving devices for police and other first responders to cut crashes at traffic stops and accident scenes.

New approaches to hearing loss

As the number of older Americans rapidly increases, so too has research into the consequences of age-related hearing loss and new ways of treating it.
